reason.tex:
%text A is a $3\times 3$ matrix we will use as an example to understand how to find Adjoint of a matrix % \begin{align} A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc} a_1 & a_2 & a_3 \\ b_1 & b_2 & b_3 \\ c_1 & c_2 & c_3 \end{array}\right] \end{align} \\ %text Start by constructing the Cofactor Matrix (see topic Cofactor Matrix), % \begin{align} CF&=\left[\begin{array}{ccc} b_2c_3-c_2b_3 & c_1b_3-b_1c_3 & b_1c_2-c_1b_2 \\ c_2a_3-a_2c_3 & a_1c_3-c_1a_3 & c_1a_2-a_1c_2 \\ a_2b_3-b_2a_3 & b_1a_3-a_1b_3 & a_1b_2-b_1a_2 \end{array}\right] \end{align} \\
%text All we need to do now is a transpose - rows to columns, columns to rows, and we have the Adjoint, %
\begin{align} Adj(A)&=\left[\begin{array}{ccc} b_2c_3-c_2b_3 & c_2a_3-a_2c_3 & a_2b_3-b_2a_3 \\ c_1b_3-b_1c_3 & a_1c_3-c_1a_3 & b_1a_3-a_1b_3 \\ b_1c_2-c_1b_2 & c_1a_2-a_1c_2 & a_1b_2-b_1a_2 \end{array}\right] \end{align} \\
%text For a $2\times 2$ matrix, it is even simpler. Follow this translation (prove it to yourself as an exercise). %
\begin{align} B=\left[\begin{array}{cc} a_1 & a_2 \\ b_1 & b_2 \end{array}\right] \implies Adj(B)=\left[\begin{array}{cc} b_2 & -a_2 \\ -b_1 & a_1 \end{array}\right] \end{align}
